text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- King Hussein gives go ahead to proceed with a 431 million dinar ($609 million) "social safety" net programme over the coming years. "We hope to attain self-sufficiency in the near future," the monarch says.

- Head of the centrist National Constitutional Party Abdul Hadi al-Majali says Jordan fears solving the Palestinian refugee issue at its expense; says Palestinian Authority has to define who is a Palestinian to avoid duality of loyalty.

- King Hussein stresses the need to improve living conditions of Jordanians and easing suffering of disadvantaged groups in society; 431 million dinars allocated to projects to include 173 million dinars to refugee camps and 145 million dinars to local councils.

- Foreign minister says no rift in ties with Israel and stresses Jordanian-Israeli ties are not passing through a crisis; stresses that Jordanian water rights issue was behind the cancellation of the meeting with Israeli officials along the border last Tuesday.
- Crown Prince Hassan calls for rehabilitating Arab economies taking into consideration the location of the region at the crossroads of East and West.
- In two separate festivals which were attended by thousands, both the Ministry of Religious Affairs and the Moslem Brotherhood mark Islamic New Year.
- King says there will be a new effort to raise living standards of Jordanians.
- King receives a call from Israeli President Ezer Weizman who briefs monarch on his talks with Palestinain leader Yasser Arafat.
